If they had come into this place and argued about the details of the legislation, opposed particular parts of its implementation, I would have had less trouble with them; but what they have done is the complete somersault. From being entirely for the idea, now they are against the idea-not the details of the implementation, but the whole idea.

Opposition members are also in chaos about what kind of opposition they really want to mount. Some of them oppose the ID card by settling for support for the tax file number. Senator West in her speech dealt with the hypocrisy of that. If people want a tax file number essentially what they are saying is that they want an identification system. They are just talking about a slightly different one. That is the sort of nonsense the Australian Democrats have argued all along. The thing that can be said on behalf of the Democrats is that at least they have been consistent in their wrongness. The Opposition has turned about-tail on that one too.

Neither the Opposition nor the Democrats addressed the difficulty of the tax file number, and that is, as Senator West has said, that not everybody has a tax file number. What will Opposition senators do about those who do not have a tax file number? What system do they propose to provide a tax file number to the many citizens who do not enjoy one at the moment? What mechanisms would they put in place to establish that tax file number for citizens? Where would that be done? Would people just be sent a letter, or would they have to front for an interview? Would they go to the tax offices around Australia? Where would they go? The Government has been very comprehensive and thoughtful in addressing the difficulties of how the Australia Card could be implemented. It has picked up on all the processes required to put this in place. It is quite clear why it wants an Australia Card system.

I turn now to the more particular points the Government has mentioned from the start and insisted on more and more, particularly in the face of the about-turn and the nonsense from the Opposition. Tempting as it is to run through the Opposition's somersault quotes, as some of my colleagues have, I will set that aside in case I have more time at the end of my speech.

I would like to move now to the particular point that seems to miss the Opposition; that is, why we should have the ID card. Why should we not do that those opposite keep suggesting ought to be done-make improvements in the Australian Taxation Office and improvements in the social security system. The point is that both systems, even if operating optimally-I do not think anyone denies that there is room for improvement but even if that improvement were implemented-still would not address the particular difficulties that the Australia Card will address and solve. Let us take the question of social security fraud. The Opposition the last time around spent a lot of time bashing us with how the Department in its evidence before the Joint Select Committee said that identification was not responsible for much of the fraud. That was only to quote selectively from what the Department said and also not to understand the intent of that comment.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Gilmore Federal Electorate-Use of Commonwealth Cars

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., pursuant to order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish briefly to draw the Senate's attention to what I believe to be the disgraceful misuse of government resources by the Labor candidate for the Federal seat of Gilmore. I refer the Senate to articles appearing in the Young Times on 13 January 1987 and in the South West News on 5 December 1986 in which Mr John Wright, the Labor candidate, offers pensioners kits advising them of his attitude to pensioners in that electorate. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Any person seeking a pension kit can obtain one by phoning John Wright on 062-75 2221 during working hours.

A call to that number is to a desk in the Australian Taxation Office, that is, the Commonwealth Taxation Office in Canberra. That is an absolute disgrace. What is more of a disgrace is that Mr Wright has arranged with his working colleagues to take orders on his behalf for the documents from people who ring in for them, and this is being done during Public Service working hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is his position?

—He is an officer in the tax department. He is often away from his phone because he appears to be able to flex off, I think is the expression, to visit this electorate that he is trying to win. It takes a bit of effort for him because he lives in Queanbeyan or Canberra, but the electorate is in the Goulburn area. He does not live in his electorate and no doubt that puts immense pressure on him to try to get into the area he is trying to win, but he does so at the expense of the Australian taxpayer. I hope that the Minister in the chamber, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), will do something about this. I intend to table the newspaper clippings from which I quoted. I find it intolerable that this number is available during working hours.

SPEECH.PARA: That is only part of it. I now quote from a letter sent by the same Mr Wright to his supporters which has come my way and which I believe raises other matters of some concern. I do not want to go into the arrangements Mr Wright made with Senator Richardson's office about sending out his material with Senator Richardson's mail, allegedly at Senator Richardson's expense. I presume that it is at the expense of the Commonwealth. They can sort that out among themselves.

I want to deal at some length with a notice that I have in my possession to all Federal Australian Labor Party candidates in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory from the Australian Labor Party South East Region Strategy Committee-SERSC-Candidates' School. It is signed by Mr Ian Henderson, the Convenor of the Candidates' School Co-ordinating Committee, and is dated 17 December 1986. By the way, the contact point for reply and other information is Ian Henderson, ALP National Secretariat, PO Box E1, Queen Victoria Terrace, Australian Capital Territory, 2600, telephone 062-73 3133. I have no reason to believe that that is anything else but genuine.

In the notice, after inviting members and their campaign assistants to a candidates' school in Canberra on Saturday 30 May 1987, we find that the program of the school would include media training for candidates, campaigning and fund raising and political strategy. The last para- graph of the letter says:
The School is being planned and co-ordinated through SERSC with the support of N.S.W. Branch and the National Secretariat of the Party,
This is the bit that concerns me. It says:
and with the assistance of media advisers to the Federal Government.

We are all well aware of the extraordinary collection of media advisers being paid at public expense who now surround this Government. The Senate is entitled to require from this Government an assurance that the media advisers to the Federal Government, who will be assisting ALP candidates, are not doing so while on the Government payroll and, if they are the same media advisers who are on the Government payroll, the Senate deserves an assurance that part of their duties is not a requirement that in their so-called spare time they attend to give this kind of advice to Labor candidates.

The clear suggestion from this is that a Labor candidate can come along to this seminar and be advised by the same people who have been advising this Government at public expense. I believe that this is an absolute disgrace. I now seek leave to table this letter from Mr John Wright and also the newspaper clippings.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I now want briefly to refer to a matter I mentioned the other night, which involves Mr Colin Hollis, the honourable member for Throsby, who made some ludicrous, nonsensical, totally inaccurate and false accusations about my alleged use of a Commonwealth car. I demonstrated to the Senate the other night that it was totally wrong in fact, that I was listed as being here in a division at the time that I was alleged to have kept a Commonwealth car waiting outside a dentist, at the expense of the Government and the taxpayers. I have already demonstrated that there was no cost to the taxpayer; that this was absolute nonsense. Mr Hollis could well be described as `having made a mistake'. That is the kindly approach in the first instance, because he was apparently not aware of the facts. He is now aware of the facts and has persisted with this nonsense. He put out a Press release tonight which repeats basically the attack against me, except that he diminished the time from one hour and a half to just over one hour that the car was waiting while I was attending a dental appointment. He said that the information he got came not from the transport office or anyone in the Commonwealth car service, but `from a member of the public who saw the car arrive-not at 10.15 but earlier'. That is totally untrue. The Press release continues:

SPEECH.PARA: who passed the car several times while it was waiting, and then waited to see who came out. It was a member of the public who happens to be a constituent.
that is, a constituent of Mr Hollis's-
she had work in Canberra and passed the information on to him.

That is a total and deliberate fabrication. It could not possibly have happened, for a very simple reason. The car did not wait outside the dentist's surgery, because it could not. This particular dentist is in a mall upstairs in a set of offices, in a building where there are a lot of offices. There would be no knowledge on the part of any casual observer that a car that stopped in a street near a mall to let me out necessarily was related to a dentist who is 130 yards up the mall, upstairs in a set of offices. This is an absolute and total fabrication. Not only did the car not wait outside the dentist's surgery, but it did not even wait at the end of the mall. In fact it went to another street, an area of parking for Commonwealth cars in Civic, about 500 yards away from the dentist's surgery. I arranged to meet the car there 30 or 40 minutes later. There is no possibility of anyone pretending that it was possible to have seen me get out of the car and go to the dentist and then come out of the dentist and get into the car. No-one could claim to have waited outside because the car did not wait outside.

We have already established that all the rest of Mr Hollis's facts are an invention. We are now having more invention. Now that Mr Hollis knows the truth and persists with this nonsense I have, outside this place, said of Mr Hollis that his determination to continue spreading these kinds of lies about me shows him to be a liar and a cheat. I have said so without parliamentary privilege and I have invited him to sue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Whatever you say outside may be all right, but you are not allowed to use those remarks inside the chamber, Senator. You should withdraw them.

—I withdraw the statements. However, I repeat that I have made them outside the chamber and I have invited Mr Hollis to sue. If Mr Hollis has any decency or integrity whatsoever, he will either apologise or repeat his totally false and fabricated assertions outside the privilege of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.41 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many medical practitioners in Australia were charged with overservicing Medicare in the financial years 1983-84, 1984-85 and 1985-86.
(2) What were the results of such charges through the courts or through internal investigations conducted by the Federal Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The provision of excessive services is not an offence, but services which are not reasonably necessary for the adequate medical care of the patient do not attract Medicare benefits. A practitioner who may have rendered excessive services is not `charged' in the legal sense of the term. However, he may be referred to a Medical Services Committee of Inquiry, which reports to me on the question of whether excessive services have been provided. I may then make a determination in accordance with the report and recommendation of the Committee of Inquiry. I may determine that the referred practitioner be counselled; that he be reprimanded; and/or that he be required to repay moneys in respect of Medicare benefits paid for services deemed to be excessive. If no excessive services are found, no determination is issued.

(2) The figures given below show the number of referrals to Medical Services Committees of Inquiry in each of the financial years 1983-84, 1984-85, 1985-86, and the result of each referral. The number of referrals does not include cases brought forward from the previous financial year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government fulfilled its obligations under the ABCI intergovernmental agreement to provide the support staff for the ABCI as requisitioned by that organisation to enable them to perform the functions assigned to them under the terms of the agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government continues to meet its obligations under the ABCI Agreement. Under the terms of the Agreement the Commonwealth is required to meet the salaries of the Director and Deputy Director. In addition, it is required to second police officers from the AFP and, as appropriate, officers from Commonwealth Departments. Permanent administrative staff are also provided by the Commonwealth and there is provision for members to be co-opted from agencies of the Commonwealth. There have been some discussions at officials level regarding apparent anomalies in the Agreement. For example, the Agreement is silent on the provision of other civilian staff (intelligence collators or information control staff) and ADP resources.
The ABCI estimates have been subject to the same scrutiny as the estimates of all other agencies and the ABCI has not always received everything they have asked for.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What requests have been made by the Police Ministers' Council for adequate support staff for the ABCI.
(1) If such requests have been made-
(a) when were they made; and
(b) what numbers were requested.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 25 November 1983 the Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) requested the Commonwealth to provide the necessary financial support for the continued development of the ABCI involving staffing proposals for five positions. On 22 January 1986 the Chairman, APMC, wrote to my predecessor concerning resources for the drug database project. A total of ten positions was involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Was there any allocation of staff made to ABCI at the request of the Department of Special Minister of State that was subsequently overturned by the Department of Finance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Staff allocation in the Public Service is based on approved Average Operative Staffing Levels so it is difficult to conceive of circumstances in which the answer would be ``yes'' to this type of question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has the Government taken to overcome the claim by the Police Ministers' Council that ``the lack of support staff is having an adverse effect upon the efficiency and development of [ABCI]''.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The words quoted in the question are taken from a document titled the ``Annual Report on the activities of National Common Police Services 1984-85''. The document is based on a report to the Australian Police Ministers' Council by the Management Committee of the ABCI.
See answer to Question upon Notice No. 1463. In addition, the Australian Police Ministers' Council has under consideration a number of development options which include the question of staffing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government been acquainted with the request for staffing for ABCI on the basis that the full establishment and operation of the drug data base, as approved in May 1985, was being delayed through lack of support staff; if so, when will the positions be filled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of the request for resources additional to the $1.5m already provided. Further action must await the outcome of consideration of development options by the Australian Police Ministers' Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government been made aware of funding for ABCI which caused curtailment of important travel, regarded as necessary by the ABCI, both interstate and overseas. Is there now sufficient funding to ensure that necessary expenditure levels be maintained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1985-86 the ABCI expressed dissatisfaction about the level of funding initially allocated for travel; subsequently funds were reallocated from within the ABCI Administrative vote which overall was not fully spent.
The 1986-87 allocation for travel is the level sought by the ABCI during the draft estimates process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: When will the full development of the ABCI drug data base be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Finalisation of a strategy including a target completion date for the law enforcement component of the Australian Drug Data Base must await the outcome of consideration of options by the Australian Police Ministers' Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has there been any amendment to the ABCI intergovernment agreement that has discharged the obligation of the Federal Government to provide the support for the ABCI.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no amendment to the ABCI intergovernmental agreement concerning the provision of staff. (See answer to Question upon Notice No. 1463 regarding Federal Government obligations).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the 1981 ABCI Establishment Agreement, which parties agreed to meet the cost of-
(a) the seconded State and Territory police officers;
(b) the normal establishment and operational costs; and
(c) the permanent administrative support staff.
(2) Has there been any change to the funding arrangements of the ABCI since the signing of the 1981 agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government attempted to renegotiate the ABCI Agreement so that the States would have to pay two-thirds of the cost of the permanent administrative staff; if so, why, and what was the reaction of the States to the suggestion from the Federal Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Police Ministers' Council agreed in December 1986 to an examination of cost-sharing options as part of its further consideration of the Australian Drug Data Base project. These options would not encompass permanent administrative staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have some States raised the question of withdrawal from the ABCI Agreement because of the Federal Government's failure to meet its obligations.
(2) Would the withdrawal of one or more of the States from the ABCI lead to it being disbanded or at least substantially downgraded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am unaware of any parties to the Agreement raising this question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister or the Department of the Special Minister of State ever proposed that the funding and/or administration of the ABCI be placed under the control of a Federal statutory authority.

(2) If the funding of the ABCI were placed under the control of a statutory authority, would the `administration and operation of the ABCI in the performance of its function' remain `independent of any one participating government or agency'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Federal Government has not put forward any proposal. Informal discussion at officer level was undertaken of the possibility of all national common police services constituting a statutory authority. The matter did not proceed further.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the workload of the ABCI increase two-fold between the time of its establishment and November 1983; if so, was there an increase in support staff commensurate with this increased workload.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the ABCI, the management of the ABCI is the responsibility of the Director and the Management Committee to which he reports. The Management Committee in turn reports to the Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC). In view of these arrangements it would be inappropriate for the Special Minister of State to be answering questions on the day to day operations of the ABCI.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What has been the proportional or percentage increase in the workload of the ABCI since November 1983 and has this increased workload been matched by appropriate increases in support staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: See answer to Senate Question No. 1502.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the latest official estimate of the annual value of heroin trafficking in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no authoritative means by which an official estimate can be made of the value of heroin trafficking in Australia.
In 1985-86, 52,335 grams of heroin were seized by the Australian Customs Service or the Australian Federal Police (AFP).
I refer the honourable senator to the publication ``Illicit Drugs in Australia-Situation Report 1986'', edited by the AFP, which contains details of price ranges/availability of illicit drugs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Prime Minister state, in his policy speech prior to the 1984 election, ``And in prosecuting this national campaign [against organised crime and drug trafficking] no resources will be spared to remove this evil [drugs] from our society.''; if so, in what way did he mean.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. At the Special Premiers' Conference on Drugs the Commonwealth Government committed itself to a long term program of assistance directed to both demand and supply drug reduction strategies. Financial support included:
some $20m p.a. indexed for an initial three year period for the education, treatment, rehabilitation and research aspects of the national campaign;

additional resources of the order of $1.5m over financial years 1985-86 and 1986-87 to enhance the capacity of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence to provide drugs intelligence to all participating law enforcement agencies;
some $5.5m over financial years 1985-86 and 1986-87 to strengthen the capacity of the Australian Customs Service to interdict drugs entering Australia; and

the provision of additional resources of some $17m over three years for additional manpower and computer capacity for the Australian Federal Police (AFP). My predecessor has also directed the AFP to give highest priority to the investigation of drug trafficking.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the then Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) tell the Senate in February 1984 that proposals to upgrade the ABCI would be part of the 1984-85 Budget; if so, what upgrading was achieved in the financial year 1984-85.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Senate was told of the Government's plans that ``the implementation of these proposals [to upgrade] is intended to be undertaken in the context of the 1984-85 Budget''. After normal budgetary processes had been completed some $1.4 million was allocated to the ABCI in 1984-85 and announced in August 1984. At that time it was noted that the ABCI allocation may become the subject of additional estimates later on in the 1984-85 financial year, when the degree of interaction between the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the newly established National Crime Authority became clearer. In April 1985 an additional $1.5m for the ABCI was announced and provided over the financial years 1985-86 and 1986-87. The total Commonwealth allocation over these two financial years is some $5.2m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Forward Estimate for the ABCI as requested in accordance with the Establishment Agreement of 1981 for the financial year 1984-85 cut by $400,000 to $1.4m.
(2) What were the reasons for this reduction.
(3) What were the specific effects of this decision on the operation of the ABCI generally, and the upgrading program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Forward estimates for the 1984-85 Commonwealth contribution to the ABCI were processed in the same manner as previous years and in line with all other 1984-85 forward estimates of Commonwealth expenditure. I would like to take this opportunity to note that the forward estimates process is intended to give a preliminary indication of forthcoming Government expenditure which is subject (in this area as in all areas of estimated Government expenditure) to continual review and refinement up to the announcement of the Budget each year.

While the estimates were reduced by $395,000 on the basis that the degree of interaction between the ABCI and the National Crime Authority was under consideration, the Commonwealth contribution to the ABCI actually increased by over $150,000 in 1984-85. Significant additional funds were included as part of the National Drug Strategy during the 1985-86 and 1986-87 as part of a co-ordinated approach to the drug problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Director of the ABCI protest to the Special Minister of State about the reduction in funding for the 1984-85 financial year; if so, what was the Special Minister of State's response.
(2) Was a further approach made by the Director of the ABCI for a special advance to be included in the 1984-85 Supplementary Estimates to enable ABCI obligations to be met.
(3) Was there a series of approximately 50 meetings preceding the final decision.
(4) Was this approach successful, and was a supplementary estimate forwarded by the ABCI.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Director wrote to the then Special Minister of State on 25 September 1984 about the developing role and workload of the ABCI and requested further consideration of the Bureau's resource needs. A review of the resource needs of the ABCI was conducted and senior officers of the Department of the Special Minister of State and the Department of Finance met with the Management Committee of the ACBI on 10 October 1984 to discuss the issues. It was agreed that a submission would be put to the Department of Finance early in December. The proposal was not received from the ABCI until 22 January 1985. It was for resources significantly exceeding those identified earlier and presupposed a significant upgrading. A submission was submitted by my Department for an additional 5 positions and $0.4m in the 1894-85 Additional Estimates but was unsuccessful.
(3) I am advised that there was a long series of meetings but it is difficult to put a precise figure on the total number.
(4) See (1) and (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the number of administrative support staff allocated to the ABCI reduced in July 1984; if so what was-(a) the previous staff level; (b) the size of the reduction; and (c) the reason for the reduction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There was no reduction in the average operative staffing allocation made to the ABCI in 1984-85 from the staff usage in 1983-84.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Forward Estimates for the 1985-86 Budget include a ministerial demand for a cut of $83 000 in allocation to the ABCI.
(2) In March 1985, a month after these cuts were foreshadowed, was the ABCI asked to re-submit its funding requests for 1985-86.
(3) Did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promise an additional $1.5m to the ABCI as part of the Drug Summit in May 1985, to be spread over 1985-86-1986-87.
(4) Did the ABCI order computer hardware and allocate salaries for 10 extra staff on the basis of this announcement.
(5) Was the ABCI subsequently refused authority to proceed with recruitment moves for the allocated positions because of staff ceilings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As part of the normal budgeting cycle the ABCI along with other elements of my portfolio was asked to identify possible savings. The ABCI responded with savings of $73,902.

(2) and (3) In March 1985 the ABCI was asked to put forward proposals for consideration as part of the Government's initiatives in connection with the National Drug Offensive. As a result the ABCI was allocated $1.5m spread over 1985-86-1986-87.
(4) The ABCI incurred expenditure of $1.0m in 1985-86 for the purchase of computer equipment as a result of the increased allocation.

(5) The approved Average Operative Staffing Level for the ABCI was not varied as a result of the Drug Summit announcement. Indeed, by early January 1986, it had come to the notice of my predecessor that computer equipment proposals alone would exceed the Drug Summit $1.5m.
The ABCI along with all agencies funded from the Commonwealth budget is required to comply with Average Operative Staffing Levels assigned as part of the budget process.
The Australian Police Ministers' Council has under consideration a number of development options which include the question of staffing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has any of the additional $1.5m Drug Offensive funding promised to the ABCI been expended; if so, in what areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, I am advised that the Department of the Special Minister of State has allocated $1.5m for computer plant and equipment as follows:
$1.0m spent in 1985-86; and
$0.5m allocated in 1986-87.

The Department agreed to expenditure of $1m in 1985-86 to purchase Rank Zerox equipment only after the ABCI Director gave a written assurance that the equipment would be sufficient to ``allow the law enforcement aspects of the ADDB [Australian Drug Data Base] to be implemented when the staffing situation has been satisfactorily resolved and further consultancy has been completed''. However, subsequent ABCI proposals sought funds for equipment well beyond that level.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: During the 1985-86 Budget preparations, did the Special Minister of State, any member of his staff, or any departmental staff advise that `the ADDB funding through the 1985-86 Budget could not be countenanced.'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As indicated in the answer to Question on Notice No. 1511, additional resources of the order of $1.5m have been provided by the Commonwealth. This funding commitment was announced by the Government as part of the Drug Summit initiatives which were authorised by Cabinet before the 1985-86 Budget was finalised. Specific Cabinet authorisation is necessary for the inclusion of funds for such initiatives in Departmental budget estimates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of the Special Minister of State seek an assurance on 31 July 1985 from the Chairman of the ABCI Management Committee that the Australian Drug Data Base (ADDB) would be operational by 30 June 1986.
(2) Were there any provisos on that undertaking.
(3) Was it achieved; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) and (3) I am advised that the then Special Minister of State had discussions on 31 July 1985 with the Chairman, ABCI Management Committee, at which the target date for implementation of the law enforcement component of the ADDB was considered. The ABCI subsequently engaged Doll Martin to prepare a proposal for the development and implementation of the ADDB project. The consultant's report was not received until after June 1986. The Australian Police Ministers' Council currently has under consideration implementation options including the question of target dates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government on 9 January 1986 advise the ABCI and/or the APMC of the decision not to provide additional staff; if so, on what grounds was this decision based.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The ABCI was allocated its Average Operative Staffing Level in the 1985-86 Budget.
In August 1985 the Director, ABCI, estimated that the proposed purchase of Rank Zerox equipment would result in substantial efficiency gains, including increases in staff productivity.
By 9 January 1986 it had come to notice that, despite contrary assurances given by the Director, ABCI, computer equipment proposals alone would exceed the allocated Drug Summit $1.5m.

The Secretary of my Department then advised the Chairman of the Management Committee on 9 January 1986 that ``I have been investigating various possibilities of bringing additional resources to bear on the design and development of the law enforcement component of the Drug Data Base.

An analysis of the ABCI salaries vote for 1985-86 has revealed a strong probability of a substantial underspend for the year. The underspend will occur due to delays experienced in recruitment of ADP staff. I would recommend that these funds be used to employ consultants/contract programmers to work on development/design activities''.

During 1985-86 consultants were commissioned to examine and report on, amongst other matters, the resource requirements of the ABCI. These reports were considered by the Australian Police Ministers' Council on 5 December 1986 and a Ministerial Sub-Committee (Commonwealth, NSW, Victoria and Tasmania) has been directed to further consider and report back to Council in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated backlog of unprocessed material at the ABCI in time and/or quantity.
(2) What methods are in hand to eliminate the backlog and to make the information of full practical use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senators' question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the ABCI, the management of the ABCI is the responsibility of the Director and the Management Committee to which he reports. The Management Committee determines the workload. The Management Committee in turn reports to the Chairman of the Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC). In view of these arrangements it would be inappropriate for the Special Minister of State as the Commonwealth representatives on the APMC to be answering questions on the day to day operations of the ABCI.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Police Ministers' Council written to the Government stating that the operation of the Australian Drug Data Base (ADDB) was crucial in order to meet undertakings made by both the Prime Minister and the Special Minister of State since 1984.
(2) Is the Australian Drug Data Base fully functional.
(3) Is its effectiveness being jeopardised by the Commonwealth's lack of funding support.
(4) Does the ABCI have sufficient staff to operate at the required levels.
(5) What requests for essential staff and equipment are outstanding or under discussion as at 7 November 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The then Chairman of the Australian Police Ministers' Council wrote along the lines suggested. He went on to welcome the provision by the Commonwealth of $1.5 million towards the cost of the further development of ABCI.
(3), (4) and (5) The Australian Police Minister's Council has under consideration a number of development options which include the question of staffing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the NSW Police Commissioner, John Avery, in his capacity as Chairman of the ABCI Management Committee, written to the Federal Government stating that ``the Committee holds the ongoing viability of the Bureau and the Australian Drug Data Base in jeopardy''.
(2) Does this indicate a genuine fear for the future of the organisation.
(3) Was the point raised because of an inability on the part of the Management Committee to make progress in achieving increased resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The NSW Police Commissioner, Mr Avery, wrote to the Secretary of my Department on 23 July 1986 expressing concern about staffing for the ABCI.
(2) and (3) I do not propose to enter into conjecture.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it true that the Victorian Government has allocated an additional 26 police officers to work full-time on ABCI targets, over and above the agreed levels.
(2) Is the work of these police being undermined by the shortage of permanent administrative support staff at the ABCI to process the information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It would be inappropriate for me as a Commonwealth Minister to answer for the Victorian Government. However it must be noted that ABCI targets are selected by the Management Committee which consists of all Australian Police Commissioners and presumably are targets also of the police forces themselves.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Federal Government provide Thailand narcotics authorities with a $9m computerised data-base if so, did the Federal Government pay for 6 computer experts and 2 crime analysts to visit Bangkok as part of providing this computer system.
(2) Is the system in operation and does the Australian Government have an ongoing financial commitment to the program.
(3) Does the ABCI receive any drug related information of relevance to Australia from that source.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The project referred to was initiated by the previous Government in December 1982 through a Memorandum of Understanding between Australia and Thailand. Australia is providing computing equipment, software and services, six ADP specialists and one crime intelligence analyst while Thailand is providing 37 support personnel and accommodation for equipment and staff. The estimated cost of the project to the end of June 1987 is some $8.6m.

(2) The Australian project team is assisting with the progressive installations and operation of the system. A joint Australian/Thai review of progress with the project has recently been completed and discussion on future project funding past June 1987 will be made against the background of this review and as part of the normal 1987-88 budgetary process.
(3) I do not propose to comment upon or speculate about the sources of the ABCI's information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Special Minister of State believe that meeting the new Drug Summit commitment was a substitute for the commitment under the Establishment Agreement; if so, did the other parties to the Establishment Agreement accept that point.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth continues to meet its commitments under both the ABCI Agreement and the Drug Summit initiatives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the Doll Martin Inquiry established.
(2) What were the 2 separate issues covered.
(3) What is the expected cost.
(4) When will it be completed.
(5) When will its report be made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Doll Martin was engaged as a consultant to prepare a technical report on a possible Drug Data Base and intelligence processing system. Phase 1 of the consultancy commenced in May 1984 and reported in June 1984. Phase 2 commenced in March 1986 and reported in August 1986.
(2) Phase 1 was a feasibility study and Phase 2 involved the analysis, design and specification of proposed systems.
(3) Phase 1 cost was approximately $22,373. Phase 2 cost was approximately $153,449.
(4) Phase 3 involves implementation and is subject to the outcome of further consideration by the Australian Police Ministers' Council (APMC).
(5) This is a matter for the APMC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 25 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Could the Minister for Health advise whether the pharmacist who holds a repeat prescription at a pharmacy on the request of a patient is acting properly and within the relevant law despite instructions from visiting Commonwealth Health Department officers who advised that in spite of the law, Commonwealth Health Department policy is that repeat prescriptions are not to be kept at pharmacies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Where a pharmaceutical benefit prescription orders repeat supplies, under regulation 26 of the National Health (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Regulations a pharmacist is required to issue a repeat authorisation and the duplicate of the prescription to the person to whom the pharmaceutical benefit is supplied at the time the supply is made.

The regulation therefore places a mandatory obligation on the pharmacist to return any repeats of prescriptions to the patient at the time the benefit is supplied. If a pharmacist fails to do this there is a clear breach of the regulation.

The spirit and intention of this regulation is to ensure portability of the repeat authorisation and a freedom of choice to the patient to have a prescription dispensed wherever he or she wishes. In addition, in some cases the retention of the repeats of prescriptions could lead to fraudulent claims being made against the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

However, patients, sometimes specifically ask the pharmacist to hold the authorisation and duplicate prescription on their behalf for future dispensing, particularly where the patient is elderly, infirm, or inclined to forgetfulness and possibly has no domestic support on which to rely. In these circumstances, the pharmacist would be acting as the agent of the patient. However, in such situations the pharmacist would have to ensure that the duplicate prescriptions and repeat authorisations were issued to the patient, and the patient formally arranged with the pharmacist that he or she would retain these documents acting as the agent of the patient.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 24 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there problems relating to plumbing, run-off from landscaping and faulty hot water services being experienced at `Woolmers Court'.
(2) Are the plumbing faults similar to those experienced at the aged units in Belconnen.
(3) Have final certificates been issued for `Woolmers Court'.
(4) They were issued when serious plumbing faults existed.
(5) What action is now being taken to rectify the problems at `Woolmers Court'.
(6) What action will be taken in future to ensure that work is completed and comply with requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the National Capital Development Commission that

(1) Yes. Problems relating to plumbing and hot water services have been rectified at Woolmers Court. The question of run-off from landscaping is being investigated and if warranted remedial work will be undertaken.
(2) The NCDC is not aware of similar plumbing faults at aged persons units in Belconnen.

(3) No. Public housing is built in accordance with the A.C.T. Building Manual. All inspections and certifications are carried out by the NCDC's Agent Architect in accordance with the Commission's standard building contracts. `Practical Completion' is achieved when the units are suitable for occupancy and certified accordingly by the Architect. The Housing Branch of the Department of Territories accepts handover of the units after an inspection by their officers and then the units are allocated to tenants. The `Final Certificate' is not issued until the expiration of the 13 week defects liability period. During this period the Contractor is responsible for the rectification of all building defects.
(4) and (5) The plumbing problems encountered at Woolmers Court were not of a major nature and have been rectified. The landscape run-off problem is being investigated.
(6) The NCDC will continue to ensure that any construction defects will be rectified by the Contractor before the issue of the `Final Certificate'.
